For any commutative semiring R and multiset s of type R, the k-th coefficient of the polynomial product of X + Œª over Œª in s equals the (cardinality of s - k)-th elementary symmetric function of s, provided that k is less than or equal to the cardinality of s.

type:

  k ‚â§ Multiset.card s ‚Üí
    (Multiset.map (fun r => Polynomial.X + Polynomial.C r) s).prod.coeff k = s.esymm (Multiset.card s - k)
name: Multiset.prod_X_add_C_coeff
docString: For any commutative semiring R and multiset s of type R, the k-th coefficient of the polynomial product of X + Œª over Œª in s equals the (cardinality of s - k)-th elementary symmetric function of s, provided that k is less than or equal to the cardinality of s.

This theorem states that, for any index type `Œπ`, any function `f` from `Œπ` to the extended nonnegative real numbers (`ENNReal`), and any extended nonnegative real number `a`, the product of `a` and the indexed supremum (`iSup`) of `f` is equal to the supremum (denoted by `‚®Ü i`) of `a` times `f i` across all `i` in `Œπ`. In other words, multiplication distributes over the supremum in the extended nonnegative real numbers.

type: ‚àÄ {Œπ : Sort u_4} {f : Œπ ‚Üí ENNReal} {a : ENNReal}, a * iSup f = ‚®Ü i, a * f i
name: ENNReal.mul_iSup
docString: This theorem states that, for any index type `Œπ`, any function `f` from `Œπ` to the extended nonnegative real numbers (`ENNReal`), and any extended nonnegative real number `a`, the product of `a` and the indexed supremum (`iSup`) of `f` is equal to the supremum (denoted by `‚®Ü i`) of `a` times `f i` across all `i` in `Œπ`. In other words, multiplication distributes over the supremum in the extended nonnegative real numbers.

Shows that
$\sum_{k = 0}^{n - 1} (e^{X})^k = \sum_{p = 0}^{\infty} \sum_{k = 0}^{n - 1} \frac{k^p}{p!}X^p$.

name: PowerSeries.exp_pow_sum
docString:
Shows that

If {f\_n : ‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù} is a sequence of smooth functions with uniformly summable sup-norms of their derivatives up to order k, then the k-th derivative of the infinite sum Œ£_(n=1)^‚àû f\_n is equal to the infinite sum Œ£_(n=1)^‚àû (the k-th derivative of f\_n).

type:
‚àÄ {Œ± : Type u_1} {ùïú : Type u_3} {E : Type u_4} {F : Type u_5} [inst : RCLike ùïú] [inst_1 : NormedAddCommGroup E]
  [inst_2 : NormedSpace ùïú E] [inst_3 : NormedAddCommGroup F] [inst_4 : CompleteSpace F] [inst_5 : NormedSpace ùïú F]
  {f : Œ± ‚Üí E ‚Üí F} {v : ‚Ñï ‚Üí Œ± ‚Üí ‚Ñù} {N : ‚Ñï‚àû},
  (‚àÄ (i : Œ±), ContDiff ùïú N (f i)) ‚Üí
    (‚àÄ (k : ‚Ñï), ‚Üëk ‚â§ N ‚Üí Summable (v k)) ‚Üí
      (‚àÄ (k : ‚Ñï) (i : Œ±) (x : E), ‚Üëk ‚â§ N ‚Üí ‚ÄñiteratedFDeriv ùïú k (f i) x‚Äñ ‚â§ v k i) ‚Üí
        ‚àÄ {k : ‚Ñï},
          ‚Üëk ‚â§ N ‚Üí (iteratedFDeriv ùïú k fun y => ‚àë' (n : Œ±), f n y) = fun x => ‚àë' (n : Œ±), iteratedFDeriv ùïú k (f n) x
name: iteratedFDeriv_tsum
docString: If {f\_n : ‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù} is a sequence of smooth functions with uniformly summable sup-norms of their derivatives up to order k, then the k-th derivative of the infinite sum Œ£_(n=1)^‚àû f\_n is equal to the infinite sum Œ£_(n=1)^‚àû (the k-th derivative of f\_n).

The theorem states that for any type `Œ±` that forms a semilattice under a supremum operation, for any function `f` from natural numbers to `Œ±`, for any natural number `n`, and for any element `a` of `Œ±`, the following two conditions are equivalent: (1) the `n`-th element of the sequence of partial supremums of `f` is less than or equal to `a`, and (2) for all natural numbers `k` less than or equal to `n`, the `k`-th element of `f` is less than or equal to `a`. In other words, the maximum value of the function `f` up to the `n`-th term is less than or equal to `a` if and only if all terms of `f` up to the `n`-th term are less than or equal to `a`.

type: ‚àÄ {Œ± : Type u_1} [inst : SemilatticeSup Œ±] {f : ‚Ñï ‚Üí Œ±} {n : ‚Ñï} {a : Œ±}, ((partialSups f) n ‚â§ a) = ‚àÄ k ‚â§ n, f k ‚â§ a
name: Mathlib.Order.PartialSups._auxLemma.3
docString: The theorem states that for any type `Œ±` that forms a semilattice under a supremum operation, for any function `f` from natural numbers to `Œ±`, for any natural number `n`, and for any element `a` of `Œ±`, the following two conditions are equivalent: (1) the `n`-th element of the sequence of partial supremums of `f` is less than or equal to `a`, and (2) for all natural numbers `k` less than or equal to `n`, the `k`-th element of `f` is less than or equal to `a`. In other words, the maximum value of the function `f` up to the `n`-th term is less than or equal to `a` if and only if all terms of `f` up to the `n`-th term are less than or equal to `a`.

for each `k ‚â§ N` (except maybe for finitely many `i`s). Then the series is also `C^N`.

      (‚àÄ (k : ‚Ñï), ‚Üëk ‚â§ N ‚Üí ‚àÄ·∂† (i : Œ±) in Filter.cofinite, ‚àÄ (x : E), ‚ÄñiteratedFDeriv ùïú k (f i) x‚Äñ ‚â§ v k i) ‚Üí
        ContDiff ùïú N fun x => ‚àë' (i : Œ±), f i x

`‚àë n, Œº s‚Çô = ‚àû`, `limsup s‚Çô` has measure 1.

The Bernstein approximations
```
‚àë k : Fin (n+1), f (k/n : ‚Ñù) * n.choose k * x^k * (1-x)^(n-k)
```
for a continuous function `f : C([0,1], ‚Ñù)` converge uniformly to `f` as `n` tends to infinity.

This is the proof given in [Richard Beals' *Analysis, an introduction*][beals-analysis], ¬ß7D,
and reproduced on wikipedia.

type: ‚àÄ (f : C(‚ÜëunitInterval, ‚Ñù)), Filter.Tendsto (fun n => bernsteinApproximation n f) Filter.atTop (nhds f)
name: bernsteinApproximation_uniform
docString:
The Bernstein approximations
```
‚àë k : Fin (n+1), f (k/n : ‚Ñù) * n.choose k * x^k * (1-x)^(n-k)
```
for a continuous function `f : C([0,1], ‚Ñù)` converge uniformly to `f` as `n` tends to infinity.

This is the proof given in [Richard Beals' *Analysis, an introduction*][beals-analysis], ¬ß7D,
and reproduced on wikipedia.
